string-array.name: quiz_names
string-array.item: Strings, More Functions, and Multi-Dimensional Arrays

string-array.name: random_encounters
string-array.item: You just finished reading this amazing book called Coders, and you think that adding it to the syllabus will help students gain insight into the tech world, even if it is a little more work for them. What do you do?

The administration tells you that counting attendance by following along to lecture slides isn’t a good method, since students can simply follow along for their friends given their netID and password. It wants you to use i-clickers for attendance. What do you do?
MP0 is out and it\'s so hard the students need therapy! You’re not professionally trained for that, but you can help them in other ways. What do you do?
You see a lot of posts on the forum and on Reddit from beginner coders claiming that CS 125 is too hard, and that it isn’t beginner-friendly. What do you do?
MP1 is out, and cheating levels have increased drastically. What do you do?
There’s an epidemic! Well, not really, but it’s flu season and just about three fourths of the students are coughing in lecture. What do you do?
MP2 is out, and it’s harder than ever! Your students are stressed out, and your TAs and CAs are beginning to agree that it’s too hard, too. What do you do?
The mid-term grades are supposed to be uploaded on self-service, but the autograder is down! What do you do?
You notice that the class average is far lower than those of the previous years’, and you want to try to fix it. What do you do?
You noticed a fairly offensive image on the forum with your face photoshopped onto another image—let’s not go into detail. What do you do?
Your underpaid and overworked TAs and CAs are done. They go on strike against CS 125 until more are hired. What do you do?
Your students have reported bugs in online grading. What do you do?
Due to heavy scheduling, the administration keeps trying to postpone the CS 125 fair. They tell you now that the Fall 2019 fair must be held about a week before Spring break! What do you do?
It’s the end of the semester and your students are getting bored. Most of them spend lectures watching Netflix. What do you do?
Your students are losing interest in lectures, and you want to keep their attention. You’re thinking about how to fix this when your cat, Xyz, jumps onto your laptop. What do you do?
It’s the end of the semester and your students are getting bored. Most of them spend lectures watching Netflix. What do you do?

string-array.name: positiveEncounter
string-array.item: Vehemently disagree and continue with your method
Reduce the difficulty of the course a little.
Turn a blind eye; the MP is too hard, anyway
Tell the students to go home and rest
Work on it devotedly, along with all your Course Developers and TAs.
Add an extra credit opportunity in MP3
Agree to hire more TAs and paid CAs
Accept the change in date and inform your students of the delay
Get the administration to block Netflix on IllinoisNet

string-array.name: negativeEncounter
string-array.item: Don’t add Coders to the syllabus
Agree to their terms and ask your students to bring i-clickers
Tell the students that they’re supposed to be overwhelmed and do nothing else
Increase the difficulty instead to teach them a little discipline
Create a complex plagiarism checker to counter the evil cheaters
Ignore it and continue with the lecture
Delay the mid-term grades a little and work on fixing it slowly
Do nothing, remind your students that office hours exist
Drown them in legal notices until they’re forced to go back to work
Aggressively pursue them until you get the date you’d initially asked for
Do not bring Xyz to lecture

resources.string: The students have been slogging on the homework daily. They really need a break.
I think it’s okay to give homework that’s a little challenging. Nothing too difficult, though… But I wouldn’t know, I’m just code.
The students seem ready to take on some real challenges in homework!
Maybe you should give an easy quiz this time. The students are really stressing over their grades.
The students would like their quizzes to be just right: not too hard, and not too easy.
The students aren’t taking the quizzes seriously enough. Maybe you should remind them that they need to properly study for this course.
The MP always ends up overwhelming a student. You should probably make this checkpoint easy.
A nice, average MP would hopefully not stress out a student but also actually make them learn useful information.
The students seem ready to take on a challenging MP!
Maybe you should make this midterm easy. The students are really stressing over it.
You should consider making the midterm difficulty just right: not too hard, not too easy.
Give the students a challenge this time round! Even if they mess up, at least the midterm is only worth 2% of their grade.
You have submitted the quiz difficulty for this week!
You have submitted the MP difficulty for this week!
You have submitted the homework difficulty for this week!
You have submitted the midterm difficulty for this week!
There are no quizzes this week. Check back later!
There is no MP this week. Check back later!
There are no midterms this week. Check back later!
There are no posts on the forum right now!
This game was created by Ishita Rao and Kanav Bhatnagar as their final project for CS 125. They cool. Pls give them an A+, they’ll give you a singular cookie.

Welcome, Geoff! You’re back for the Fall 2019 semester to teach CS 125. Your students last Spring were moderately happy with your work, congrats! However, that means that your new batch of students and the university have high expectations from you to do a great job, yet again. \n\nLet\'s get started! Choose the number of weeks in the semester:
This is your handy help page, informing you of the various tools that’ll aid you in teaching your class. Tap a subheading to get more info on it.

The semester is divided into 5/10/15 weeks depending on what you chose. You’ll be able to go to the next week only after planning the difficulties for homework, quiz (if any), midterm (if any), and MP checkpoint (if any). Check the forum and university email every week for helpful tips!


You have two satisfaction bars: student satisfaction, and university satisfaction (including administration, you, and anybody who is paid to run CS 125). Your actions in the game will affect these bars. If, at any point, either of the bars hit zero, you automatically lose the game.


Every week, you’ll face a random encounter, and your actions will affect student and university satisfaction. Choose wisely.


You have three bonuses: 
Chuchu the dog/Xyz the cat (either one): boosts student satisfaction 
The real Geoff Challen: boosts university satisfaction 
Java Chad Ben Nordick: boosts both student and university satisfaction by a little bit 
You can use each bonus only once per game.
This is where you’ll learn what your students feel about the course so far. It can be helpful to know where you’re going wrong, or what you’re doing correctly.

This is where you’ll periodically get email from the university, letting you know if they’re happy with what you’ve been doing. This, too, can be useful in pinpointing your errors to help you make the next week better.

Here, you’ll set the difficulty of each aspect of the course for the following week, from 0 to 9 (0 is the easiest, 9 is the hardest). There’ll also be advice that should help you decide the difficulty. A few things to note: 
1. 	Midterms are available in weeks 4, 9, and 14. 
 Quizzes are not available during these weeks. 
2. 	MPs start from week 2, and won’t be available in week 	 14.
